awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2024 New England Hardware Security Day (NEHWS2024)
awd_abstract_narration:
The New England Hardware Security workshop is a regional, one-day conference designed to bring together hardware security researchers, industry participants, and students in order to develop connections and collaborations between these groups.  This year's workshop will take place April 5, 2024, in Worcester, MA.  This award will fund student participation in the workshop, increasing the number and diversity of students who can benefit from attending.  Participating students will be able to present their work at poster sessions, allowing them to get feedback from a variety of experts.

This award will provide travel support to up to 100 students; the regional nature of the workshop further reduces travel costs, accommodating a much wider range of student participants in terms of their career stage and experience in hardware security than most conferences.  In particular, the workshop will target early-stage researchers who are not yet attending national conferences, as well as students from disciplinary and personal backgrounds that might not otherwise think to attend a conference on hardware security.  This will both increase the chances that participants take up hardware security topics in their future work, as well as provide participants with ways to connect with potential future employers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
New England Hardware Security Day (NEHWS 2024) was a 1-day workshop held on April 5, 2024, at the Worcester Polytechnic Institute. The workshop had a total attendance of 179, of which 86 were students. This NSF travel grant supported student attendance at the workshop. The workshop featured 32 student-presented posters in the poster competition, a lineup of outstanding talks, tutorials, and a panel. 

 

Sharad Malik gave the first keynote talk on "Don't Trust, and Verify," and Andreas Olofsson gave the second keynote talk on "Composable chiplets and implications for disaggregated design." 

 

The panel discussed "The Good and the Bad of Hardware Security." It featured the distinguished panelists Wajdi K. Feghali from Intel, Gayatri Perlin from BAE Systems, Dominic Rizzo from zeroRISC, Edward Suh from Meta/Cornell University, and Silviu Chiricescu from Draper. 

 

The event was jointly organized by researchers from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Northeastern University, University of New Hampshire (UNH), UMass Amherst, Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI), and Yale. The organizing committee was Yarkin Doroz, Yunsi Fei, Fatemeh Ganji, Daniel Holcomb, Koksal Mus, Patrick Schaumont, Berk Sunar, Jakub Szefer, Shahin Tajik, Xiaolin Xu, Menggjia Yan, Qiaoyan Yu, and Kemal Derya. The event helped to strengthen bonds within the New England hardware security community and exposed students to state-of-the-art research topics in a field of significant importance to our region.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/18/2024
Modified by: Shahin Tajik
